text: The first light is breaking over the fields and hedges of this timeless rural landscape. With the clanking of bells a herd of cows makes its way to the first milking.

The room is simple with a few sticks of worn wooden furniture. A young woman is asleep under the covers, with cat curled up on the bottom of the bed. This is GABRIELLE SIDONIE COLETTE, or as she will later be known, simply COLETTE. A voice calls from down the corridor - her mother SIDO.
Gabrielle! The girl stirs but her eyes remain stubbornly closed.
Gabrielle!! Wake up.
(murmuring) Let me sleep!
Come on, Gabrielle!! Sido is now at the door frame. A handsome country woman, forthright and practical - nobody’s fool.
What time is it?

It’s 8 o’clock. Willy is coming today. Colette just murmurs. SIDO (cont’d) (CONT'D) Good. Then you won’t want your hair doing. She disappears. After a moment, a head emerges from under the pillow and looks to the empty doorway. We get our fir look at the milky skinned, precocious, whip-smart, Colett
A train belches steam as it slowly moves toward the stati A MAN IN A TOP HAT leans out of the window.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 2.
Dismounting, Willy sees a waiting carriage across the pla

Wearing her best frock, Colette carries a large TEA SERVI down a corridor and into the main room. Willy is seated, conversation with Sido and JULES, the patriarch, an affab old soldier, with one leg, who is smoking a pipe.
And how is Paris these days, Willy?

It’s a hot bed! It’s “Electric!” Heaving with artists, writers, poets, all seeking to say something profound... most of them are too young or crazed but still, they do generate a certain... life force! Colette, her hair neatly plaited, puts the cups out for everyone then takes over the teapot and pours.
We were going to see a play in Paris - weren’t we?
La Tosca.

I was at the opening. I wouldn’t bother, quite frankly. Sarah Bernhardt did her best, she always does, but the piece is too overwrought in a particularly feminine way... melodramatic in extremis! Tears on the stage but all dry eyes in the house.
Maybe I'11 go and make up my own mind.
Well, just remember... if a book bores you, you can throw it away. If a painting is garish, you close your eyes. (MORE )
Whereas bad theatre is like dentistry; you are compelled to stay in the chair, having your skull drilled, until the entire grizzly procedure is over.
Good point, Willy. Painful business!
Though I imagine it must hold a secret source of enjoyment - for the dentist. Willy raises an appreciative eyebrow and chuckles.
Indeed... Oh - I almost forgot. A small gift. He reaches in his pocket and pulls out a small package. S unwraps it to find a SNOW GLOBE OF PARIS.
Thank you. I’ve read about these.
Shake it. She does and looks, fascinated, at the twirling flakes.

Look, Sido. A snow globe. She holds it up for her mother. EXT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE — LATE AFTERNOON 7 M. Willy bids good-bye to Jules, Sido and Colette, before the carriage moves off. Colette is holding her comfortabl old cat which she hands off to her mother.
Sido, I’m going for a walk.
Change your dress first.
I’1l stay on the path.
Change it!  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 4.
Now in a different dress, Colette starts to come down sta Hearing her parents talking in the kitchen, she slows up, listening carefully.
There’s something about him I find suspect... something disingenuous.
Oh, not in my reckoning... He’s a good man. He has a reputation, yes, but there comes a time ina man’s life to settle down...and she’s the right age for it. She’ll be twenty next time around.
I just worry that he won’t understand her. That girl said her first word at nine months. She was always reading, way ahead of her class, she was the lead in the school play - every year.
My dear, would anyone be good enough for you?
Hmmph. Now on the ground floor Colette waits outside the door as her parents talk. Sido moves into view by the kitchen sin
Have you finished the letter to his father?
I keep starting but I can’t seem to finish it. A girl without a dowry, -that just doesn’t happen in their circles. They may cut him off if he marries her.
So they call it off. The world won't end. As her father talks, Colette sneaks back up the last five stairs...  10 11 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 5.

Sido, he clearly adores her - he’s visited four times. He’ll give her status, not to mention a tremendous cultural life - the theater, the opera. He’1ll give her Paris for heaven's sakes! Colette comes clumping down the stairs, slightly too loud and into the room.
Can I go now?
Yes. Take this - for blackberries. (hands her a pot) I’m making a tart tomorrow. And don’t be late back.

(eye roll) I won't... Sido watches her daughter, not without suspicion, as she takes off across the garden. EXT. SAINT-SAUVEUR — COUNTRYSIDE - LATE AFTERNOON 9 Colette runs down a path, then backs up, picks a few prim blackberries, and continues on. She moves through the woods, with the stealth of an anima then breaks out across a broad green meadow towards a bar EXT. OLD BARN — LATE AFTERNOON 10 She approaches the gaping black door of a dilapidated bar
Entering the darkness, Colette blinks to re-adjust her eyes. A flutter of wings attracts her attention. She turn to see an ascending pigeon. Then, below, a tired old hors
Where are you?
Over here. Enjoying the simple pleasures of country life! Behind a partition, she sees Willy, reclining on a pile o straw.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 6.
You look at home in the hay.

I think I might be! And you look like a beautiful young country girl. Right there. With the light...What’s that? Colette shows him, putting the bowl between them as she nestles beside him. Her hands are blue with the juice. She looks WILLY (CONT’D) Your fingers are stained. (he takes her hand) Mm... Maybe I could just leave Paris behind. (he takes a blackberry) You could feed me berries. I’d catch a fish with my teeth. Then come back here to my cave. Like a bear. Bliss.
I'd like that.
(he caresses her braids) Your hair is a phenomenon.
In the village, they call me “the girl with the hair.”
I can see why. I’m sure you’re famous here in your village.
A little. down. COLETTE (cont'd) (CONT'D) How long until your train goes?
In about 40 minutes. But I have to walk to the station.
Normally takes me about 15 minutes. Will probably take you 20.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 7.
Yes. Right. So if my calculations are correct...
We have time - if we’re quick.
Yes, we do. He smiles, moved by her beauty, kisses her, then breaks off.
What?
I just can’t say how unimaginably happy I am, Gabrielle.
So am I. He holds her by her shoulders firmly.

I adore you. He kisses her shoulder. Feeling his beard brush against h skin, Colette smiles as they move into a passionate embra nearby horse chews hay as they proceed to take their clot off. 11A INT. COLETTE’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 11A Colette sprawls out on the bed, her hair in plaits. She i writing a letter in a school exercise book in pencil, res on an encyclopaedia.

Dear Willy, As I walked home by the river, the light shining through the trees, my heart filled with a kind of delicious pride. After all, you know all those fine women of Paris...so I must have something. (smiles to herself) ) I want to wake up next to you. Trace your profile with my finger while you sleep. Know that the day is ours. That life is ours for the taking. We will be so entire and so happy, my love.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 8.
At the Wedding Party, Jules is making a toast Colette and Willy in front of a MIXED CROWD of WEDDING GUESTS.

It’s the proudest time in a father’s life, but also - I now find - one of the saddest. I have to hand over my beloved daughter, who has lit up our lives for so long, with her wit, her brilliance, her beauty. I will miss you, Gabrielle. Almost as much as your mother will... A murmur of acknowledgement from the assembled. Colette smiles at her father, and catches her mother’s eye, holdi back emotion.

But it is no small compensation that I give her to a man of such inestimable standing. There are many celebrities in Paris but few are famous enough to be known by -- by a single name. WILLY - Welcome to the Colette family. Everyone cheers. Colette turns to her new husband, glowing.

A COUNTRY BAND strikes up. COUPLES polka around the garden. A COUPLE OF PEASANTS carry trays of drinks from a kitchen tent to the GUESTS. Some CHILDREN chase a chicken through dancers. WILLY (cont'd) This is definitely a country wedding.
It’ll make a good story -- in Paris.
You'll be the story in Paris, Gabrielle. Just wait ‘til they get a look at you. Willy twirls Colette round and round and round...  13 14 15 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 9.

Across the river Seine - the center of the demi-monde; th Left Bank. This is not postcard Paris - the buildings are sooty and chimneys are filling the sky with smoke. On the quay, PEOPLE go about their business as a YOUNG ATTENDANT lights the gas lamp. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - BOUDOIR - EVENING 14 MATILDE, the maid, is winching Colette into a very tight red froufrou dress. A knock on the door.
Are you ready yet?
No - not yet. (to the maid) What do you think, Matilde?
It’s pretty, Madame. Colette looks at herself critically.
Willy returns and prepares to knock again.
We should try to get there before it ends.

I’m coming... The door opens. Colette is in another dress - the one fro their meeting in Saint-Sauveur. Matilde hovers nervously. COLETTE (CONT’D) Is the carriage waiting? Willy looks disappointed but together they proceed throug SEVERAL ROOMS to the front door. We get a feeling for Wil apartment - a warren of dark rooms overcrowded by boxes, and Wagnerian bric-a-brac. Willy, it seems, is a hoarder.
Where’s your new dress?
It looks ridiculous. I couldn't breathe in it.  16 17 18 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 10.
That thing cost me two hundred and thirty-seven francs.
I know. We'll get it adjusted.
(half joking) More money! They exit. EXT. ELEGANT PARISIAN STREET — EARLY EVENING 16 The carriage pulls up. Colette is fiddling with a spot of tooth powder on her dress.
What is it?
...It’s tooth paste.
(amused) My God! Here... He rubs a little spit on it. WILLY (CONT’D) That’1ll do. Let’s go in... INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — HALLWAY 17 They approach the giant door.

Ready for the lions...? She lets out a nervous exhale. The double doors glide ope INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - MAIN ROOM 18 Willy and Colette proceed into a reception room filled wi the beautiful, the sparkling, and the eccentric of Paris’ Golden Age. The mirrors have been polished; so have the epigrams. Amidst the gas lamps, the India rubber plants, and the zebra skin rugs, the energy is bouncing off the walls. Willy acknowledges hellos and nods to people along the wa With her tight braids and country dress, Colette looks dr in this sea of peacocks.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 11. They arrive at a circle of conversation -- that of MME. D CAILLAVET, the hostess, the debonair COUNT MUFFAT, and a few SALONITES and FRIENDS.
It’s monstrous. I can’t look at it.
At least it’s temporary.
Oh here’s Willy -- Willy! Eiffel’s Tower, are you for or against?
I’m for it, if a little jealous of this giant erection in the heart of our capital... belonging to someone else. Laughter from the circle.
You rogue, Willy. And you’ve brought a... an orphaned relative?
A secret love child?
(acknowledging their mockery) Very good... May I present to you my wife, Gabrielle-Sidonie Colette. Colette curtsies politely, her cheeks flushing.
Pleased to meet you.
Delighted. Well, astonished actually. You have caught the slipperiest eel... How does one do that?
I’m not sure... Colette smiles, a little nervously.
Where are you from, you sweet thing?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 12.
I’m from Saint-Sauveur-en-Puisaye... (no reaction) ...it’s in Burgundy.
Hence the dress!
Have you “relocated,” Willy? This is apparently hilarious and there is laughter.
Tst...ignore him... But how on earth did you two meet?
Our fathers served together in the army...
(riding over her) Willy married! The wild days are done, eh?
You’re quite mistaken, sir. The wild days have just begun. Willy smiles at his new bride’s moxie. A business-like young man rushes up to Willy. This is PIERRE VEBER.
Willy, thank God you're back. That short story for La Forgue —
Pierre. Let me introduce you to my wife, Gabrielle.
What..? Very pleased to meet you. Before she can speak, he turns to Willy with a more urgen VEBER (CONT’D) It’s due on Tuesday and you haven’t given me the slightest clue.
Amuse yourself for a moment, Gabrielle.  19 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 13.
I will. Willy draws Veber aside to continue the shop talk.

It’s simple - an eight hundred word sketch. Small coastal resort, damp bathing-costumes. The perfect place to rejuvenate a de-iodized constitution. A buxom girl approaches, long legs... Colette is left standing by herself. Nearby, a silver tra displays a living turtle with an exquisitely jeweled shel She takes a lettuce leaf from a salad dish and feeds it.

Poor thing. You want the earth and the grass don’t you? Across the room she sees Willy, with Veber, lifting the g on a wall candle and lighting a cigar. Feeling out of sorts, she moves through to an adjacent ro where... INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — MUSIC ROOM 19 A STRING QUARTET is giving a recital to the assembled. Across the room a group of SALONITES are clearly discussi her. Embarrassed, Colette finds an empty seat. She looks across the room - the salonites are still whispering.
Are your ears burning? Colette looks up and sees - Marcel SCHWOB, an intellectua with a humane gleam in his eye. He sits next to her. SCHWOB (CONT’D) I’m Schwob, a friend of Willy's.
Hello. I’m Gabrielle. Willy described you to me.
I hope he was kind.
(wryly) Hope costs nothing.  20 21 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 14. Schwob raises an amused eyebrow, then looks out into the room where people are stealing glances at them.
The modern day mob, aren’t they? (Colette nods) But their goddess is gossip instead of the guillotine. Are you feeling overwhelmed?
A little.

They may look grand and intimidating. But just imagine them shitting. Each and every one of them. Colette looks at him, incredulous. SCHWOB (CONT’D) Well they all do, don’t they? Across the room, AN IMPORTANT-LOOKING GENTLEMAN, waves to Schwob. SCHWOB (CONT’D) (to the Gentleman) Good evening, Sir! (to Colette) Try it.

They may look grand and intimidating. But just imagine them perched over a chamber pot. Each and every one of them. INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - VARIOUS ROOMS 20 We follow Colette as she searches for Willy in the sea of SOCIALITES. She walks through rooms where PEOPLE are now dancing in an avant garde fashion then through a series o SMALLER COMPARTMENTS, where SERVANTS are polishing glasse and CHEFS are preparing hors d’oeuvres, past palms and oi lamps, to a distant room at the far end of the salon. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — SMOKING ROOM 21 From the doorway, Colette spies Willy leaning on the mantelpiece talking to a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN in a red dress. The woman leans in close to him, laughing. He whispers something and she laughs even harder.  22 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15. There's a shrieking coming from the corner of the main ro Colette turns to sees the crowd laughing as a BOHEMIAN po milk into an upright piano. INT. HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE — MOVING — NIGHT 22 Colette looks out the window into the night-time streets. After a moment, Willy ventures a question.
So what did you think of the salon? WILLY (CONT’D) That was essentially - what you witnessed tonight - everyone who’s anyone in Paris...
Was it..?
Who did you like? Who did you talk to?
I liked the tortoise. I think he was as bored as I was.
I suspect you were more intimidated than bored?
No. I found them...shallow. Pretentious.

Ah, you're reading them wrongly. It’s not pretension so much as exaggeration. The ideal is to be authentic yet larger than life. To present a personality with a capital P. You could do it too with your country girl charm ... She turns to him.
(interrupting) Did that woman have a capital P?
Which one?  23 24 25 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 16.
The one you were talking to? In the red dress. With the breasts?
Nicole D’Allier? That was just... flirtation. It means absolutely nothing.
Then why do it?
It’s what one does... to pass the time. It staves off boredom. You’re reading it all completely wrong. Colette sighs, frustrated. Willy changes tack.
Maybe...

Forget about all of them now. Any way - haven’t you heard the news? Willy is married. Happily married. And he’s going home with his bride, who he loves very much. Colette nods, looks at him with a half-smile. He is forgi

The carriage rides off into the distance. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - MORNING 2 From directly above, we see Pierre Veber dash up the stairs. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - ENTRANCE ROOM 25 Colette is seated at a desk, carefully roughing out a letter. She writes a line then crosses it out, rephrases it. There’s a knock at the door. Veber enters in the hallway and looks through to Colette’s small room where she sits with a large pile of correspondence.
Hello, Veber.  26 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 17.
Gabrielle. It’s cold out there today.

I’m under house arrest so it doesn’t affect me. (gestures to the other room) Schwob’s already in there. We follow Veber through the maze-like apartment to Willy' office. He passes through the front room which is semi-da its furniture covered by dust sheets. INT. WILLY’S STUDY 26 Willy, mid-flow, barely notices Veber enter. Schwob sits an oil lamp, taking notes.

So something like...”all the humor and vivacity descends into...a dreadful melodramatic swamp! Or... it released the toxins of man’s very soul, leaving the audience pale, and nauseous as though having eaten a bad oyster.”
It’s a bit extreme. The ending was actually quite touching. Willy thinks for a moment.
Hmmph - I prefer my version. He finally acknowledges the new arrival. WILLY (CONT’D) Veber!
Willy. Schwob.
(to Schwob) So drop in those embellishments and file it at The Echo before six.
Will do. (he leaves.)  27 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 18.
The factory’s on fire... We’re on fire...! Sit. I’ve hada remarkable idea - it could be, anyway...
What is it?
I’m going to launch a novel.
What?!
We've had stories by Willy, music reviews by Willy. Now Willy’s first novel. There’1l be enough literature in it to appeal to the high-brows and enough filth for the great unwashed.
And who's going to write it?
-.-You are! Veber shakes his head, absorbing this. WILLY (CONT’D) Brandy? Cigar?
Schwob stops to chat to Colette by the desk. Matilde is stoking the fire.
Are you writing for him too? He’s made you one of his ghosts already?
Just letters...
You're fastidious... exacting.
A lot of crossing out, you mean.
...well, yes.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 19.
Willy copies them out afterwards - so they are in his handwriting.
No one has handwriting like M. Willy. 28 INT. WILLY’S STUDY 28 Willy is completely absorbed in his pitch, sweat beading from his forehead as he paces.

He first sees her, Monna, held aloft on the shoulders of her admirers.. She’s eighteen, beautiful, wild and she’s from the streets, eats men up, never wears a corset. And our hero, Renaud - a writer, a genius - he’s captivated by her. She seduces him in her shabby rooms - five entire days of carnal bliss - but she has a powerful hold over him. She instinctively understands his base desires. We wonder - will Renaud escape - go back to his wholesome friends and his burgeoning career - or will he be dragged down by her toxic embrace, forgetting all about writing to live forever in a sexual quagmire. .? Willy ends with a flourish, eyes slightly damp. 29 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT 29 Colette gets up from her desk, as Willy escorts Veber through the apartment.
How long do you think it will take?
Two or three months?
No no...weeks, Veber! It has to be weeks! Write for four hours at a time...
All right... I’1l1 come back to you if I get stuck.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 20.
Yes...Just write it...and fast! Let’s get some money coming in.
Goodbye, Gabrielle. She waves. The door closes on Veber. A piece of wallpaper has pulled free of the wall. Willy rubs it back in place.

Chaos. Working in these conditions. Absolute...chaos. Willy comes over to his wife and kisses her as they walk back into the front room. WILLY (CONT’D) You’ve married a literary entrepreneur. What a phenomenal disaster.
You’ve married a country girl. Not a penny to her name.

We're utterly doomed aren’t we? They both laugh. She hands him the rough draft of the letter. He peruses it quickly. WILLY (CONT’D) Perfect... but how about; “The contract you have sent me seems eminently fair, with only one shortcoming - the money.” Always pump something up before you prick it. You get more of a “POP” that way. Unexpectedly, Willy farts.
Willy!
Intimacy in all its savage abandon, my love! I’ve a few meetings today. Let’s meet at La Mascotte at nine. No make it ten.
..-Goodbye Willy.  30 31 32 33 34 35 36 37 38 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21. Colette watches him go. MUSIC COMES UP FOR THE NEXT
It is greenish, uneven, and mottled. Using a tiny pair of scissors, a hand is etching the letter "W.”
Willy, Colette, Schwob, Veber and a COQUETTE, are finishi up a meal, drinking champagne. Willy is regaling them wit an anecdote as he pays the bill with a roll of notes.

As Willy walks down the aisle toward his seat, he is in h element. He nods acknowledgements and greetings to everybody who is anybody. Colette follows a couple of ste behind. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - ENTRANCE ROOM - DAY We see the etching progress - WIL. The creator is none other than Colette, alone, absorbed in this labor of love
Colette starts pulling sheets off old furniture in the living room and opening up the blinds.
In bed together, Willy is reading the evening paper as Co nuzzles into his chest. He indicates a cartoon drawing - himself with his trademark top hat - that Colette finds amusing.
Colette completes the etching of W I LL Y on the kitchen window, taking a moment to admire her handiwork. MUSIC ENDS.

Colette walks towards home, turns into the courtyard and collects the mail. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - HALLWAY/LIVING ROOM She enters, already opening the envelope and walks throug the house perusing the letter - that is written in green ink.  39 40 4l 42 43 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 22.
(murmuring) No...you’re a liar. Disgusted, she crumples it and throws it to the ground.

We follow close on Colette as she walks determinedly. The streets seem abrasive, dirty, polluted. Several STREET WALKERS ignore her as she walks by. She checks the addres on the crumpled letter, looks up at the building.

Colette walks across the courtyard, up the stairs, across balcony and tries the door to a small apartment. It’s locked. Then she hears a familiar voice and moves over to look through a small window. INT. LOTTE KINCELER’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON 4l
That’s 153 plus 278 plus 34 plus 106 for your hats... That makes it 571. For one month, Lotte...
Do you want me to look cheap? Willy is with the voluptuous LOTTE KINCELER. Between them the damning evidence: an accounting ledger.

But for that money I could be laid five times as often by a prostitute. EXT. LOTTE’S KINCELER’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON 42 There’s the sound of a woman’s raucous laughter. Colette turns to see TWO SEX-WORKERS across the courtyard. As she turns back, Willy sees her at the window. Lotte instinctively grabs a pair of dressmakers scissors.
Ah, my dear. You’ve come to fetch me.
Now walking back down the stairs, Colette is struggling mightily to keep her emotions in check as Willy blusters.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 23.
She’s not a disreputable woman. There’s even a play about her - it’s a shit play but nevertheless... I wonder who the hell wrote that letter?
I don’t care who wrote it.

She’s no rival to you, Gabrielle. I promise, I’1l never sleep with her again. But - you have to understand - this is what men do. We are the weaker sex. We don’t have your strength. We are simply slaves to our urges. And here in the city - it’s perfectly acceptable to... Colette flies at him with inarticulate rage.
I don’t accept it! You’ve been lying to me. All this time! I wait for you all day long! And I never ask you for anything because you say we have no money.
It’s true - we have no money.
Because you spend it all on her!
I really don’t!
Then when you get into our bed...and I touch you...and I kiss you...and you say you’re too tired...every night...no! No!
I’ve been inattentive. I’1l make amends. He reaches out to her.
Don’t you dare touch me! She spits out the words with such venom that they bring h to a halt as she walks on.  44 45 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.
Gabrielle! I gave up my inheritance for you! My bloody freedom!
Go to hell! She exits through the large beaten-up gateway.

The train pulls into the station. A solitary figure waits the platform - Sido. EXT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE — BACKYARD - DAY 45 Sido and Colette are hanging out laundry. Colette seems t be only half-listening - her mind is elsewhere.
...the Laurent girl had her baby last week. It was over nine pounds, but she managed well enough. She called her “Monique Frangoise.” The christening is next month. Oh, and the Durands moved away.
Really? Why?
He inherited a house. In Lorraine. I‘1l miss them. Colette manages a half smile.
I’m glad that you’re home. How long do you think you'll stay?
I don’t know, Sido.
It must seem boring to you. Compared to Paris.

No. Not at all.  46 47 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 25. INT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE - PARLOR — DAY 46 Colette is stretched out on a sofa, reading a book, absently stroking a cat in her lap. A loud clock is ticking. Sido appears at the doorway.
You must eat something.
I’m not hungry.
You’re always hungry. Gabrielle... you’re not..? {pregnant}
No. I’1l eat later. Sido turns to leave but looks back at Colette.
Come outside. Help me with the tomatoes. EXT. SIDO’S KITCHEN GARDEN - DAY 47 Colette and Sido are kneeling together in the soil. They tie some young tomato plants. An ANT crawls up one of the stems.
Agh - ants. There must be honeydew...
(feels the leaf) Yes.. it’s sticky.
The white flies have probably got to it. They'll have sucked all the juice.
We need some ladybirds?
Or a spider. There’s a big one that’s dangling in my room. I'1l catch her and put her to work out here. Colette stops, looks at Sido.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 26.
Did you ever feel like you were playing a part, Sido?
In what way?
As a wife... or a mother... That you were just going through the motions? Sido thinks. Inspects the other leaves.
Sometimes as a wife.. Never as a mother. Why? Colette shakes her head, perturbed.
Is he good to you Gabri..? (Colette’s eyes tear up) What is it, my love? Colette finally opens up...
Nothing’s how I imagined it.
Come here... Colette falls into her mother.
My darling kitten. No one can take away what you are - no one. You’re too strong for that. Always have been. Trust no one but yourself.
I know.
What’s he done to upset you?
Nothing... Nothing. (she pulls away) It’s all - just - new... That’s all. I must get used to marriage. Sido nods, looks at her daughter who looks away.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27.
Better to make marriage get used to you.
Willy and Colette walk along the dappled banks of the gre slow river. She is distant. He is persistent.
Are you happy to be here?
Yes. It makes the city seem even more foul...
Well, you are a country girl... She rolls her eyes. WILLY (CONT’D) Did you miss me?
(lies) No, not really.

Life has been...awful without you. Just dead. His tone grows more emotional. She holds firm. WILLY (CONT’D) I don’t feel like myself at all. Everything seems...utterly pointless. I can’t even write anymore... You mean more to me than all the women of Paris put together.
Have you sampled them all?
Please don’t mock me.
You’re happy to mock everybody else...
It’s true. It’s all horseshit... Words are deceptive little bastards... (MORE )
but if you trace mine to their source - to my bruised, aching heart...
I wouldn’t credit that as the organ of origin. He snorts.
You know me too well.
I can read you like the top line of an optician's chart.
That’s wonderful. Did you make it up? (she shakes her head exasperated) Just...tell me what you want, Gabrielle. And I’11l do it. She turns faces him.
I know who you are, Willy... And maybe I knew all along. But I want you not to lie to me.
I won't. Never again! I promise.
I don’t want to be treated like a little wife at home. I want to know what’s going on. Whatever it May be. I want to be... part of things.

You will be. You will be part of everything. He gives her his most sincere eyes. He puts his arms roun her and their voices get quieter as they walk further awa WILLY (CONT’D) ...and I’1ll even buy you a dog.
I’m being serious.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 29.
So am I. (he looks around) This river is so beautiful.
Yes, me and Luce used to come swimming here after school.
You did? She was your best friend, wasn’t she?
No - but she was always with me.
Willy is now in bed, Colette is undressing. They talk quietly so as not to wake Sido.
Sometimes she could be sweet.. but she could also be very annoying.
In what way?

Well, she was clumsy, more than anything. One day in winter, when the first snows started, I made a compact little snowball and smuggled it into the classroom. As Miss Terrain was writing I passed it along to the next person.. She strips down to her underclothes, shivers slightly.
Brrrrrr.
Get in. I’m like a pot-bellied stove. Colette gets in and clings to him. Willy warms her hands.  50 51 52 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 30.
It finally got to Luce.. who “dropped” it..We both got detention. ..she’d do anything to be close to me. Willy laughs.
I bet she did. He kisses her. They re-engage passionately and make love.
Sido, in her nightgown, carries an oil lamp down the corridor. From Colette’s bedroom comes the rhythmic creak of the bed springs that she does her best to ignore.

An aerial shot moves over the rooftops, churches, squares and streets of Paris. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT 52 Colette comes out of the kitchen eating a peach. A little BULLDOG comes scampering after her. This is Toby Chien. S hears an argument and moves stealthily through the apartm to ascertain its source. Through the door she sees Pierre Veber (angry) and Schwob (diplomatic) in front of Willy’s desk.
Get out! Both of you! This is harassment!
Willy, come on. You’re not being fair.
This is the third time I’ve had to come round and ask you for it!
Then stop coming round and bloody well asking!
I am close to being evicted. You owe me 400 francs. You’d get the advance from Ollendorff you said!  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 31.
And I will - by Friday.
You said that last week.
A factory needs to pay its workers, Willy!
Go on strike then! Get some other idiot to hire you! Leave me alone! Both of you! I’1l have your money by Friday.

You'd better bloody have it! Veber walks briskly into the living room, nods to Colette too angry to speak, and exits. Schwob follows, saying goodbye. Willy emerges, forlorn, and starts to get ready to leave.
Damn them! They’d never get published by themselves. I lend them my name, my reputation... I take all the risk. And there’s no money. We simply need more output.
You could get another writer in.
And pay them with what? We only have about 1000 coming in this month - 300 from the Echo, 425 for the next vamp novel and 250 from the music reviews. But it doesn’t cover our outgoings.
How can we spend that much?
The mortgage, Matilde, restaurants...
You always pick up the bill, Willy, however many people join us.
It’s expected.  53 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 32.
And the casino. And the races...
What do you want me to do? Live like a monk? Or a peasant?
I’m just saying we could economize. Mademoiselle Terrain always used to say, “Look after the pennies and..” Then lightning strikes...
You... You!
What?
You could write them up. Those stories of Saint-Sauveur you told me last year. They could be Willy’s next novel.
My school stories?

Yes. There may be something there...You must start straight away, my love. Aim for four hours at a time - the wolves are at the door! He goes back to his study. Colette’s mind is racing. INT. ENTRANCE ROOM — MOMENT’S LATER 53 Sitting at a desk, exercise book open, Colette dips her fountain pen in the ink. A statuette of Willy is perched the front of the desk, overlooking her. She writes SCHOOL NOTES BY GABRIELLE-SIDONIE COLETTE on the first page.

My name is Claudine. I live in... Montigny. I was born there in...1881. I shall probably not die there.  54 55 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 33. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - LATE 54
From directly above, we see Willy trudging upstairs.
Moments later, a rather tipsy Willy enters the bedroom. Colette is in bed, her eyes wide open.
Why aren’t you sleeping?
I only just stopped writing. Willy sits on the bed, belches, and takes off his boots.
Did you manage four hours...?
Twice that. At least.
Really?! You must be a natural!
I’ve changed a few things...for the story. But it might ruffle a few feathers back home.
Don’t worry about the facts. You can add a character, make up an event. Adapt it to the times! All people really want is the feeling, the emotion - that great sweep of narrative.
So I should just write what I want?

Yes! No one will ever dispute it - and if they do... “It is the hand that holds the pen that writes history.” Spontaneously, Colette comes over to him, wraps her arms around him from behind and nibbles on his ear. He doesn’t respond.
You're not in the mood?  56 57 58 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 34.
I’m tired as a bear in winter... Save it for the book!
MUSIC STARTS UP. We see Colette label a new exercise book SCHOOL NOTES PART 3 before she starts on the fresh page.

“These are the copses, where bushes spitefully catch your face as you pass. Those are full of sun and strawberries and lilies-of-the-valley and...snakes. I’ve shuddered there with choking terror at the sight of those dreadful, smooth, cold bodies gliding in front of my feet.’ She is completely absorbed.

“I feel so much alone there, my eyes lost far away amongst the trees, in the green, mysterious daylight that is at once deliciously peaceful and a little unnerving because of the loneliness and the vague darkness.” INT. WILLY’S STUDY - MORNING 57 There’s a pile of five notebooks on Willy’s desk with a ribbon round them and a label that says “For Willy.” Seated behind his desk, Willy unties the precious package picks up the first book and settles in to read it. After a few pages he takes a cigar and lights it.
Colette is playing with TOBY CHIEN on the floor. She gets up and looks at the grandfather clock in the hall - 1:30.
Willy emerges with the books. Colette is on the sofa with the dog, a novel open in front of her. He smiles, congratulatory but awkward.
What?  59 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 35.
Well... there we are. You did it. I take my hat off to you.
And?
It’s... beautiful. I spent the whole day in Saint-Sauveur.
You don’t like it?
I do...
Truth?
Yes. The nature descriptions are... charming.
“Charming...?” Willy heads off to boudoir.
Yes, perfectly charming! Sorry, I need to take a piss.
What else?

Nothing - really - it’s a truly wonderful depiction. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM 59 She follows him into the bedroom. He goes into the adjoin boudoir, takes out a chamber pot and starts pissing. She flops onto the bed.
..-And?
We won't be able to get it published is the shame of it...  60 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 36.
What's wrong with it?
Honestly...? She nods. He takes a breath. WILLY (CONT’D) So...I’1l treat you like any other writer I’m giving a report to, shall
Yes.
Except I love you. I adore you. Let’s be clear about that.
Just tell me. He finishes up, zips up, and comes into the bedroom.

There’s nothing driving it. No plot. A novel by Willy... It grips you from page one. Yours has... (he gestures) ...too many adjectives. Some of the characters are interesting but overall... Well, it’s just too cloying. Too...feminine. She says nothing, stares at the floor, anger mounting.
Well that was a waste of nine months.

Not if you enjoyed it. Not wanting to break in front of Willy, she storms off, through the apartment. INT. WILLY’S STUDY 60 Colette slams the door behind her, eyes brimming with tears. She opens the notebook and looks at the first page It says, “School Notes by Gabrielle-Sidonie Colette.” She takes a pen, crosses out her name.  61 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 37. And stops, leaving the single word “Colette.” She looks a it for a moment, tears in her eyes, and underlines it. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - MUSIC ROOM - EVENING 61 A makeshift stage, where the famous mime artist, WAGUE, performs a lip-sync sketch, accompanied by a PIANIST and FEMALE SINGER. The audience is transfixed by his mastery the form. Colette and Schwob are at the edge of the crowd. Colette dressed in black and white, her style feels modern and ed well ahead of the fussily-dressed socialites.
Wague’s mesmerizing, isn’t he?
Yes - he’s the king of cantomime... The song plays out its last few lines. Everyone bursts in applause.
Let’s get a drink.
Two champagne glasses are taken off a tray.
(to the servant) Thank you, Geraud.
Cheers. They clink glasses.
How’s it going with your book?
It’s gone. I tried but it wasn’t any good.
I can’t believe it.
Willy hated it. I don’t care. I don’t need to leave a mark on this world. (MORE )
Give me a flock of starlings and that will intoxicate me. Something real. Not just doing lines for the headmaster.. (takes a moment) Did you always write, Schwob?
I didn’t really have a choice. It was simply... There.
Does it make you happy?

Oh god no! I do it to prevent me from going mad. But sometimes, occasionally, it will transport me. This registers with Colette. Despite her bravura - she mi it. They are interrupted by a beautiful couple; GASTON an JEANNE de CAILLAVET.
Hello Schwob! Good to see you.
Hello Gaston, Jeanne. Do you know Colette?
I think we've been introduced but... I don’t remember that name.
It’s new - in a manner of speaking.

Well then, I will think of this as our first meeting. Schwob looks from one to the other, sensing a definite energy. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - ENTRY ROOM 62 Madame de Caillavet is demonstrating the newly installed LIGHT SWITCH to WILLY, who seems distracted.
It’s so easy. On and off. No more sooty candles.  62a COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 39.
Yes, maybe one day they will do my building.
It’s so much safer too. Even if the light is a little... bright.

Indeed. If you’1ll excuse me. Willy makes his exit and looks through the crowd for Colette. He rounds a corner and sees, through one room in which PEOPLE ARE DANCING, into a far room where Colette, GASTON and JEANNE DE CAILLAVET are sitting together. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - SMOKING ROOM 62a The newly introduced friends are all already quite tipsy. They are sitting in front of a MIRRORED WALL that reflect the DANCERS. Gaston is reading Colette’s palm. As Willy stares, a flicker of jealousy passes through his eyes.
You have a long life line. Very strong head line - here. And your love line splits in three.
And what could that mean?
Who knows? Gaston laughs, somewhat flirtatiously.
So many intersecting lines.
I have the hands of a man - see. She measures up to Gaston - hers are larger.
You have a touch of Hermes, Colette. There’s something androgynous about you.
No, I know what it is. You’ve the soul of Narcissus! Filled with sensuality and bitterness.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 40.
My soul is filled with beans and bacon rinds. You’1l find nothing else there. They all laugh. Willy arrives in front of them.
Willy, you ogre, how are you? We've been greatly enjoying the company of Colette - now she is no longer hiding her light under a bushel.
Quoting the good book, Gaston? You may remember a little verse about coveting other men’s wives.
And you may remember one about not trying to remove a speck from your brother’s eye with a log in your own.
(amused) Touché Gaston. Your wits are improving... somewhat. We’d better go now, darling.

His first play was absolute rubbish - but his mother runs a salon, so of course it was a huge success and he was praised to the skies for his brilliant “writing” and sublime “talent.” Unctuous prick... He was after you.
Willy, he’s not that type. Besides they just got married.
They’re no longer on honeymoon, my dear. Colette looks at him, slightly amused...
Your jealousy is misplaced.
Why so..?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 41.
It was actually his wife I found interesting.
Jeanne?
Yes. Willy considers this. COLETTE (CONT’D) What would you think of that?
Well, that’s a different case.
It is?
Perhaps... Willy smiles to himself.
From above we see two burly men ascending the staircase. 65 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY - 1898 65 A knock at the door. Colette answers to two rough-looking bailiffs.
Good Morning, Ma’am. I need to speak to the gentleman of the house.
What is it?
Monsieur Henri Gautier Villar - Is he in?
You can speak to me about whatever it is.
Sorry ma’am. Willy walks up the hallway.  66 67 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 42.
Yes. What is it?
Sir, I have a repossession order for two arm chairs, one armoire, one oak desk.
Do you have the court papers?
Here you are. All in order. Willy surveys them and resigned, steps to the side.
Willy?
It’s only bits of wood. (to the Bailiffs) The chairs are in the front parlour. Armoire’s in the bedroom.
With all my clothes in...

Clear it out! I’1l see to the desk. She storms off in exasperation. Willy goes into the offic INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - OFFICE 66 The desk is surrounded by piles of paper and envelopes. H clears the papers out of the second lowest drawer and ope the bottom drawer. Inside are a stack of school notebooks Colette’s novel. He picks them out of the drawer.
Ready?

Take it! Take it away! He opens the book and flips through a few pages. Then a f more, his curiosity aroused. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY 67 Willy sits on a single chair in the middle of the room. This time he’s engaged - gripped! He makes margin notes i spidery handwriting.  68 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 43.

(to himself) I am a bloody idiot. Then, he skips back to the first page where it says “Scho Notes by (crossing out) Colette.” He neatly rips out the page and screws it up. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - WILLY’S STUDY — NIGH In a pool of gaslight, Willy and Colette are seated at th desk. Willy is going through his notes.

..-example, “it’s a lovely spring morning,” liven it up. How about: (grand gesture) “Perhaps it’s the season. It’s too fine - almost disgracefully fine.” She scribbles it down. WILLY (CONT’D) And page 29 - that scene with Luce. (he finds it) I’ve added: “she brushes up against me suggestively, her blue eyes half closed and her mouth half-open.”
That’s quite louche.

Louche sells, my dear. Trust me - all we need is a little more spice, a little less literature. I know what men want. And so do the publishers. Colette ponders this for a moment - not completely satisf
And you really think they’1l take it?
Yes! Ollendorff will go nuts for it.
(ironically) As you did on first reading.  69 70 71 72 73 74 75 75a
Well never mind about that now. We've got to work work work...

head_text.subj: MUSIC COMES UP AND CONTINUES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING MONTAG

text: The presses are rolling, pumping out copies of the novel. EXT. PRINTER’S COURTYARD - DAY 70 Crates of the book are being loaded onto a HORSE-DRAWN WAGON.

A SHOP CLERK builds the Claudine books onto a pyramid- shaped display. Behind is a sign: “CLAUDINE AT SCHOOL, BY WILLY.” INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — DAY 73 Rachilde (the journalist) is reading her own review out loud to a crowd that includes Willy.

",..Claudine is a young girl froma small village, yet, she is all of us. Feisty, opinionated, selfish and sensual, she astounds us with her moxie, her desires and her crimes! The crowd let’s out an “Oooo.”
A Cousin Bette-type OLD MAID is in line with the book. In front of her, TWO SCHOOL GIRLS have purchased a copy.

A YOUNG NANNY is reading the book, ignoring the CRYING BA in the perambulator beside her. EXT. CONVENT - DAY 75a A nun has abandoned her holy book to read Claudine.  76 77 78 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 45.
Jules watches, as Sido opens a package revealing the book
Look at that!
(critically) Yes, look at it... INT. SALON — DAY 77 Rachilde continues reading her rave review - to Willy.
“It took an extraordinary man to define this modern young woman. Willy, your book will change the world.." (she raises a glass) To Claudine!
To Claudine! Schwob and Colette watch from a corner.
All Paris is saying your husband is a genius.
And what do you say?
He is, if that book is anything to go by. Colette smiles, indicates Willy with her eyes.

Look at him. I haven’t seen him as happy for a long time. In the center of the room Willy is up on some FRIENDS shoulders, uncorking champagne. Colette gives Schwob a tight lipped smile. Something is rankling her but she won confess it - yet! MUSIC ENDS.
Willy and OLLENDORFF, the publisher, are finishing up a meeting in OLLENDORFF’S double high book-lined office.  79
Well, we’ve never had one fly off the shelves like this before. Quite a phenomenon. Everyone’s talking about it. And you know who’s buying it? Young women!
Really, I thought...that’s interesting.
We've also been having enquiries about theatrical rights. Any thoughts?
Of course, the theatre is the next logical step! With as large a stage as possible!
It’s the theatre-going public which will make you rich, Willy.
Make us all rich, my dear Ollendorff. They laugh as they leave the room.
Colette is waiting by a carriage outside. She and Ollendorff coming down the stairs, talking but can’t quite make out what they are saying.
So what size are you thinking of..?
Perhaps - 20,000 units or 25,000 somewhere in that ballpark. I’m waiting to see what the pre-orders are like back from the sellers.
And what kind of return would that yield?

Well, we’re calculating about 3 francs a unit profit - so, yes - it’s a tidy sum. 79 sees Willy business, The men push through the double doors and are now fully audible.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 47.
Mme. Willy, a great honor.
A pleasure to meet you.
Listen! Claudine At School is heading for her third printing.
Excellent.
I believe that Willy based “Claudine” in part on your school days?
Yes, I believe I had a little something to contribute. Ollendorff chuckles. Willy’s smile is stretched thin.
Well, I’m very glad your experiences have borne such wonderful fruit. Very nice to meet you, Madame.
Willy climbs in next to Colette.
Gare de Lyon.
Where’re we going?
You'll find out.
Willy is uncharacteristically quiet.
Is something wrong?
What do you think is wrong?
What. .?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 48.
Finally...finally we’ve a success. And then you imply that I’m not the true author of it.
I didn’t... Most books are “based on” something.
Listen, we’re holding dynamite here. We have created something very powerful. But if it goes off at the wrong time it will blow our bloody heads off.
It was only Ollendorff. He’s your publisher, Willy.
Schwob also said something.
Schwob’s part of the factory.
People love to talk. They’1l praise you to your face, but as soon as you turn around...Tch! The knives are in your back. You don’t know the mentality here. I do.
I know it well enough to write a book that’s the toast of Paris.

Shout it to the streets then. Tell people. Roll up for the massacre... Colette sighs, Willy really is quite upset. The matter seems to cut to the core of his identity. WILLY (CONT’D) I’m sorry. Perhaps I overreacted... Anyway, I’ve a surprise for you.
What is it?
Then it wouldn’t be a surprise... We're going to the country. Colette smiles, puts her head on his shoulder.
Good. This city is driving me mad. 82 EXT. FOREST — DAY 82 Colette and Willy walk through trees, holding hands.
What’s that one?
Lime.
And that one?
Douglas Fir.
And that one?
Chestnut...A weeping Chestnut.
I don’t know why you love nature so much. Animals are vile to each other.
Animals are honest at least. They never lie.
Well yes, my dear, that is because they can’t speak. They come out of the trees into a clearing. There is a small lawn in front of a neoclassical country home. WILLY (CONT’D) Look at that!
Yes, it’s somebody's house.  83 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 50.
Wonder who lives there.
It’s beautiful.
I’m thirsty. Let’s see if they'll stand us a drink. He marches towards the house. She follows.
Willy, they might shoot at us!
Willy and Colette stand at the door. He knocks and rings bell. He waits a moment then rings again.
Wait... they might be upstairs.
Or deaf... They’ve been deafened by all the country silence.
Shhh... I thought I heard something.
Give me a kiss. Willy is on good form and charming Colette. She kisses hi aware too that the door might open.
Someone might come.
Good... He tries the door, it’s locked. Kisses her again. WILLY (CONT’D) Put your hand in my pocket. There’s something there for you.
Willy! He leads her hand downward. Slightly puzzled, Colette reaches into Willy’s pocket and retrieves... a key!  84
Allow me. 51. Willy takes the key, puts it in the lock and turns it. Th lock springs open.
84 They enter the formerly-grand old house - still beautiful but dilapidated. The rooms glow luminous in the last of t sun.
What do you think?
...-Whose house is it?
For you, my love, my heart. Lest Paris drive you mad.
What?
It’s yours. You’re always talking about missing the countryside. Willy kisses the key and gives it to Colette him and then again at the house.
Willy, I can’t believe it.
Somewhere for you to write. And be Colette hugs him lovingly, then breaks off.
So...where did you get the money?
I got an advance from Ollendorff. 25,000 Francs.
For what?
For the next book. “Claudine in Paris.” who stares at alone.  85 85a 86 88 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 52.
What?! I can’t do another Claudine.
Just write about us! Our lives! Our friends! Change the names. Create gossip!
Willy...
We'll talk about the details later. (he looks up at the house) So...do you like it? Colette takes in the house’s impressive dimensions.
It’s indescribable.

No such word. A good writer should be able to describe anything no matter what. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE — LIVING ROOM — DAY 85 Inside, WORKERS are scraping the paint off the living roo floor. The room is unfurnished with peeling wallpaper. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE 85a Two workers carry in a sofa. Colette follows carrying a c

Colette digs a wild patch of garden. She is sweaty and co in earth but hugely exhausted and content. She plants car turnips and sweet pea shoots below their sticks. In the background, we see the hoops of an OUTDOOR GYM. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE — LIVING ROOM — DAY 88 Colette watches from the window as a carriage pulls into the driveway. The floors are now polished, the wallpaper redone, the place fully furnished.  89 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 53.
This is it? Your total output for all these weeks? Willy stands, holding a few manuscript pages.
I had to do the house - all the repairs. The painting, the tiling...pruning the roses.
Bugger the roses. We have a deadline.
It’s actually harder to write out here... Alone. And I don’t want to write another Claudine.

Are you out of your mind? Claudine is a franchise! Do you realize how rare this moment is? When people are begging for more? Come. He walks her through the house and up the stairs. WILLY (CONT’D) What would the headmaster do if Claudine had not done her homework?
Willy. Don’t be silly.
(serious) What would he do?
(sarcastic) Make her do lines? Put her over his knee and tan her hide?
Correct. He arrives at the door of the study and stands expectantl at the door jamb as she walks past him into the study.
I‘1l start tomorrow.  90 91 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 54. But Willy closes the door and turns the key in the lock. COLETTE (CONT’D) No! Willy!
Write!
Willy!!
You will do as I say! I will return in four hours and I expect to see pages. He pockets the key and goes off.
Frustrated, she tries the door handle. It’s locked.
Willy!! This isn’t funny. She bangs on the door, anger building. COLETTE (CONT’D)

(kicks the door.) Bastard...absolute...arrogant bastard! I’1l write the bloody book! And I‘’11 tell them it was me! Me! Me who wrote it! Bastard! I‘11 tell them! Claudine is mine! Mine! She stands back breathing hard. Then turns with a look of resignation to the writing desk.
She sits for a moment, still smarting from the exchange, her pen in the ink and writes “Claudine in Paris.”

Close on a book - CLAUDINE IN PARIS It is revealed as part of a HUGE shop display. A LARGE SI announces “THE LATEST NOVEL FROM WILLY.” In front of it i a large pyramid of books. MUSIC ENDS  92 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 55.

A beautiful day, PARISIANS are promenading and riding bicycles and velocipedes in the open air. Colette and Wil are pedaling a tandem. She’s at the front, putting in mos the leg work, he, true to form, is taking it easy at the back. Under the trees, a cafe has been set up with delicate fol chairs and small round tables. A few dozen SOCIETY TYPES enjoying tea and cakes. Depositing their tandem by a tree. Colette and Willy approach. There is a feeling that all eyes are on them. Walking through the tables they go past a beautiful red-h heiress, named GEORGIE Raoul Duval. She is taking tea wit companion, a pretty young girl named LILY.
(whispering) Colette and Willy are here!
So they are. Don’t stare. Across the patio, Colette and Willy are seated by a WAITE Georgie takes out a small card and scribbles a note.
Go take this to them.
Post-exercise the couple are eating cake.
Mmmm. It’s good.
Indeed. He looks round. WILLY (CONT’D) How many people here do you think are reading Claudine in Paris - right now?
I don’t know.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 56.
At least three quarters, I'd say. And those who haven’t yet will soon catch up. He notices Lily weaving through the tables towards them. WILLY (CONT’D) (to himself) What comes this way?
M. Willy, Mme. Colette, I have a note for you....from Mrs. Raoul Duval. Clearly a little starstruck, she hands Willy the note and surveys it.
(remembering) Mrs. Raoul Duval. Georgie Raoul Duval?
Yes.
Oh... wonderful!.. Please go tell your mistress we accept her invitation and look forward to her delightful company.
(thrilled) I will! And off she goes.
Who is she?
